Unpack or bind values into the calling environment.

Source: R/unpack.R
to.Rd

Unpacks or binds values into the calling environment. Uses bquote escaping. NULL is a special case that is unpacked to all targets. NA targets are skipped. All non-NA target names must be unique.

to(...)

Arguments

...

argument names to write to

Details

Similar to Python tuple unpacking, zeallot's arrow, and to vadr::bind.

Note: a reference to the unpacker object is written into the unpacking environment as a side-effect of the implied array assignment. Also, can not unpack into a variable name same as the un-packer's original declared name (to).

Examples


# name capture version
to[a, b] <- list(5, 10)
print(a)  # now 5
#> [1] 5
print(b)  # now 10
#> [1] 10

# bquote re-direct to value in variable using .()
# Note: the bquote .() step is potentially confusing, as the user
# can't immediately see where the value is being assigned to.
# Also, quotes are allowed.
a <- 'x'
to[.(a), 'b'] <- list(20, 40)
print(x)  # now 20
#> [1] 20
print(b)  # now 40
#> [1] 40
print(a)  # still 'x'
#> [1] "x"

# into and to have the attribute dotpipe_eager_eval set to TRUE,
# so they do not need to be written as .(intro(a, b)) to trigger
# eager function eval in the pipeline
list(55, 15) %.>% to(a, b)
print(a)  # now 55
#> [1] 55
print(b)  # now 15
#> [1] 15
